message_1:
What is the enthalpy of combustion for methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions, given that the balanced equation for the combustion reaction is:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)

Assume that all reactants and products are in their standard states and use the following standard enthalpy of formation values:

ΔH f° [CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔH f° [H2O(l)] = -285.8 kJ/mol
ΔH f° [CH4(g)] = -74.8 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy of combustion for methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions, we can use the following formula:

ΔH_combustion = Σ ΔH_f° (products) - Σ ΔH_f° (reactants)

From the balanced equation, we have:

1 mol of CO2(g) and 2 mol of H2O(g) as products
1 mol of CH4(g) and 2 mol of O2(g) as reactants

Note that the standard enthalpy of formation for O2(g) is 0 kJ/mol since it is in its standard state.

Now, we can plug in the values:

ΔH_combustion = [1 × (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-74.8 kJ/mol) + 2 × 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH_combustion = (-393.5 - 571.6) - (-74.8)

ΔH_combustion = -965.1 + 74.8

ΔH_combustion = -890.3 kJ/mol

Therefore, the enthalpy of combustion for methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions is -890.3 kJ/mol.
